The village has a population of approximately 1,000 people nestled in the hills and terraced around a manmade lake. The reserve encompasses 12,355 acres. A community leader meets you, keen to explain the genesis of the village, which started as caretakers of the reforestation project after decades of deforestation devastated the forest landscape. In the trees, you find colorful blossoming orchids. For a different view of the lakeside and canopy, you can follow your guide into the trees to zip line down along the lakeshores. The wind blows against your skin. You fly down from platform to platform, listening to the quiet of the treetops. An occasional Cuban Trogon, the national bird, twitters along the branches. Their iridescent plumage shines against the green leaves. After your bird-like soaring over the village, you make the hike to the former 19th-century Buenavista Coffee Plantation. You can sip a freshly roasted and slow brewed coffee in the restaurant housed inside the former master’s residence, which offers a sweeping panorama of the estate. Few things are better than enjoying a quiet moment accompanied by a pristine view.

dayInfo.title: Varadero – Embracing Words and Sound
dayInfo.description: Today you leave the seductive shores of Havana behind, making your way first to the outskirts of the city to the San Francisco de Paula neighborhood. Ernest Hemingway lived at home known as Finca Vigia, which stands for Lookout House, from 1939 until 1960. The home allows you a small insight into the life of the famous American author who wrote two of his award-winning books while living in Cuba. The house contains approximately 9,000 books positioned around every room, including the bathroom. In the garden, you catch the aroma of freshly blossomed flowers. In the afternoon, you make your way to the town of Matanzas. The antique streets have a new sheen and polish inspiring the literary and musical heritage of Cuba, lending itself to the nickname, “Athens of Cuba.” You see past the wrinkles of the aged buildings and into the cheerful, undefeated character of the culture. Danzon and rumba, two of the country’s most popular forms of dance, began in the dancehalls of the city. Music continues to spill out of cafes and clubs at all hours of the day inspiring locals to move spontaneously through the day. Once you settle into the city, you have your first taste of Matanzas during a private dance lesson. Your instructor moves your body to the same rhythm as the music. You glide in time, imitating the footsteps your instructor showed you until the dance fuels you both.

dayInfo.title: Varadero – Rural Life of Cuba
dayInfo.description: In the morning, you can hear the water brushing against the white sand shores of Cuba’s coastline. The birds are most active in the cool breeze of the sunrise. They twitter and chirp in the canopy near the coast. Coconuts fall from the palm trees landing safely in the sand. Your guide leads you to a craft workshop where artisan craftsmen create works engaged in Cuban culture and community life. Continue to the city of Cardenas to witness streets tantamount in Cuban history. In the 1850s, a Venezuelan adventurer and army of American mercenaries raised the Cuban flag along the streets of Cardenas for the first time. Three renovated museums showcase the history of the city and Cuba along the city’s main plaza. The real life of Cuba opens itself to you, showcasing the dilapidated buildings and communal housing many people reside in. Horse-drawn carriages ride through the streets making it look like time has left the city behind. For an active adventure through the wilderness, you make your way to the Cuevas de Bellamar. A former slave in the 19th century discovered the caves while working in a nearby limestone quarry. The stalagmites grow from the cave floor, and stalactites drip condensation from the ceiling. Travel 100 feet through a narrow corridor into a lit room glinting with natural crystal formations. Cold water trickles into a small pool that locals call the “Fountain of Love.”

dayInfo.title: Camaguey – Climbing into History
dayInfo.description: The scent of the seaside drifts through the palm trees creating an enticing amalgamation of sweet and salty. You have an early breakfast this morning before making your way back to Jose Marti Airport for your flight to Camaguey. The city is located in the center of the island between abundant coastal allure and lush rural landscape. The cobblestone streets meander around the preserved historical center, twisting into a purposeful labyrinth that once protected the city from pirates. The design confused pillagers and invaders while providing residents cover. Your private transfer meets you at Camaguey Airport CMW and escorts you into the heart of the historic city. Plaza San Juan de Dios connects the city to its colonial past. The buildings encircling the square have Mexican architectural elements due to the country’s status as the capital of New Spain up until the 19th century. A former hospital on the eastern edges of the plaza house the Museo de San Juan de Dios. Restaurants behind the indigo buildings fill with rich music and succulent cuisine. The museum has a cloister from the 18th century and a triangular rear patio with Moorish elements. The exhibits chronicle the history of the city through the décor and paintings.

dayInfo.title: Camaguey – Cradle of Cuban Culture
dayInfo.description: Many of the buildings in the historical center of Camaguey have open, leafy inner patios. Large jars once contained water. The breeze would blow through the patio and carry a refreshing mist from the top of the jar. Today, the earthenware jars act as a symbol of the city, commemorating the city’s past and strength. Today your guide leads you on an all-encompassing tour of the city and its surroundings. Funda del Catre Alley is Cuba’s narrowest street at a length just over seven-feet wide and more than 250 feet long. The small, stunning, central Plaza del Carmen opens to a view of Iglesia de Nuestra Senora del Carmen, a quaint church bordering the eastern edge of the square. Street lamps create a cozy atmosphere. Cobblestones pave the space. Locals read newspapers and gossip about the daily life in town. It is a tiny respite for you to enjoy a moment in the colonial ambiance of the city. Make your way to Galeria Colonial for an evening of unfettered fun. The complex starts the night with a cabaret, where you can watch the show turn from stage-lit magic to encompassing musical dance party.

dayInfo.title: Camaguey – Embracing Spirit
dayInfo.description: In the morning, locals return to their places in the quiet squares to soak in the sunlight and read the newspaper. Outside of cafes, old men sit playing dominoes, enjoying their time in the shade. Mercado Agropecuario Hatibonico is a small market off Carretera Central. Vendors practically sing to visitors to look at their wares. Cuban free enterprise juxtaposes the government stalls. Purveyors of herbs and secret elixirs call out to you, eager to explain their ointments that solve all kinds of afflictions. The plant nursery contains dwarf mango trees and dangling orchids. The market has a character unto itself that embodies the distinct ambiance of Camaguey. When you are ready, your private transfer meets you at the hotel and escorts you Camaguey Airport CMW to begin the journey home.

tourName: An Immersive Cuban Tour to Havana, Vinales, Soroa & Trinidad
placesVisited: Havana, Pinar del Rio, Vinales, Cojimar, Soroa, Sierra del Rosario Reserve, Trinidad, Sierra Escambray, Cayo Leguano, Bay of Pigs, Cienfuegos
generalInfo: The rhythms of Cuba are orchestrated by the musical notes of salsa, the captivating dances of Santeria, and the wholesome birdcalls of the jungle mountains. Your custom tailored tour immerses you in the purity of the island’s emerald-clad bio-reserves to the open embrace of locals, eager to impart an understanding of their culture through a slice of their daily life. Hummingbirds dip their beaks into freshly opened flowers. Kids fly kites on the rooftops of Havana. Glassy water reflects flamingoes’ pink feathers. The mixture of history and contemporary living on colonial streets is sure to captivate you.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Cuba First
dayInfo.description: The beauty of Havana emanates from historic buildings, classic American cars, and an ineffable spirit. Your private transfer awaits your arrival at baggage claim at Jose Marti International Airport. The moment you disembark the plane, you feel as though you have entered a different world, set in the past of Soviet relations and Caribbean colors. Once out of the airport, you find blue, white, and red murals decorating the walls of the Havana suburbs. Socialist-friendly messages stand out with black block lettering. The tower of Revolution Square rises above the cityscape at a height of 358 feet. During state celebrations, the plaza, which encompasses five square miles, fills with Cubans eager to hear political figures speak about the nobility of Cuban people. The tower was designed to resemble a star. It faces the silhouette of revolutionary figure Che Guevara, which decorates the side of the Ministry of the Interior. When you near the heart of the Old City, the image of classic Havana brims with life. Live music calls out from restaurants and cafes, filled with bands dancing to the rhythm they create. Classic cars park in front of a mixture of crumbling facades and refurbished colonial homes. Artists set out their canvases and capture the life of the city in paint, because a photo can never seize the spirit of the people properly.

dayInfo.title: Havana – The Beauty of Vintage
dayInfo.description: In the morning, classic cars roar their engines along the narrow streets of Old Havana. Horses pulling buggies around Parque Central offer a glimpse of the city’s rich history. Castillo de los Tres Reyes del Morro guards the bay from pirates as it has since its inception in the 16th century. Your guide meets you at the hotel after breakfast, eager to show you the remarkable history and antique beauty of Havana’s oldest neighborhood. Your tour begins at the Catedral de San Cristobal. A rose window filled with blue, gold, and black stained glass adorns the façade. Franciscan monks erected the structure in the 18th century. It remains one of the oldest cathedrals in the Americas and even housed the remains of Christopher Columbus from the late 18th century to the late 19th century before they were moved to Spain. Tacon Street is the only preserved wooden street in all of Cuba, and stands in front of the Palacio de los Capitanes. The 27 murals from the colonial era have garnered 12 Tacon Street’s reputation as the “Sistine Chapel of Old Havana.” The floor-to-ceiling murals were discovered from under 27 layers of paint. As of 2004, nearly 500 homes had recovered old murals dating from the 18th and 19th centuries. The artistically covered walls at Tacon Street provide historians a window into the lives of colonial residences of a bygone era. Each scene tells of former customs in high society, from clerics to damsels, slaves to courtiers. One mural shows a Versailles style garden in Cuba’s lush tropical environment.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Galleries and Galas of Havana
dayInfo.description: Havana paints a different picture from the rooftops. Chicken coops and private vegetable gardens overtake small plots. Young boys cast their kites in the sea breeze. The sounds of the city fade underneath the height of the rooftops, creating a secret space for locals to retreat to. After breakfast, your guide leads you into the suburbs of Havana, following in the footsteps of the American author Ernest Hemingway. He settled in Havana between 1939 and 1960, penning his award-winning novels For Whom the Bell Tolls, and The Old Man and Sea , the latter of which was based in the Cuban fishing village of Cojimar. The home is known as Finca La Vigia, which stands for “Lookout House.” Cubans knew Hemingway for venturing out into the sea with locals and casting his line with unusual humility. The museum has captured the writer’s daily life while displaying Hemingway’s home as he left it. Papers are strewn across the bed. Hunting trophies decorate the walls. Approximately 9,000 books fill the bookshelves, line the walls, and fill the empty spaces throughout every room of the author’s former home. The typewriter on display causes chills to run down your neck. In the evening, you make your way to the vibrant restaurant of Bodeguita del Medio, a bar and restaurant in Old Havana where Hemingway, along with internationally renown writers such as Pablo Neruda and Gabriel Garcia Marquez, would sip sweet and herbaceous mojitos and dine on juicy pork shank accompanied by fried plantains.

dayInfo.title: Vinales – Raising Pinar del Rio
dayInfo.description: In the morning, the waters of the Atlantic Ocean splash against the sea walls lining the Malecón. After breakfast, your private transfer greets you at the hotel and leads you along the coastal avenue en route to the stunning countryside landscape of Vinales. Local men set out on the thick walls and cast their lines into the water in search of a fresh catch for the day. The contemporary high rises of the Vedado district cast a striking contrast to the colonial buildings of Old Havana. You pass the elegant structures on 5ta. Avenue, where flags wave in the breeze in front of the different country consulates. A tree-lined walkway separates the traffic down the center of the boulevard. Locals jog or stroll underneath the shade of lush oak trees. Outside of the city, the lush grass rises around the edges of the former military airport, which now houses the national aerial museum. The farther west you travel, the more rural the atmosphere becomes. Pass a large chicken farm looking out onto untended fields of tall grass. Horses graze in the distance. People ride down the narrow street on wooden buggies pulled by horses. The classic American cars seem out of place traveling down the secluded road. Before you reach the town of Vinales, your transfer pulls into a small tobacco farm. You immediately notice the red color of the soil. The region is known for growing Cuba’s finest tobacco. A guide greets you at the entrance to the farm, keen on leading you through the cultivation of tobacco in Cuba. Farmers loosen the soil around the thick, textured leaves in the ground. Chickens cluck and roost near the edges of the field. A thatched roof hut contains the drying leaves, each individually placed on a thick pole. The process can take weeks before the leaves are ready for rolling. The aroma is pleasant and slightly fruity. At the end of your tour, the farmer offers to roll you a fresh cigar and can even teach you the traditional method of rolling one of Cuba’s coveted treasures.

dayInfo.title: Vinales – Marvels and Mogotes
dayInfo.description: In the morning, a small haze settles over the Vinales Valley. Your hotel looks out to the rising mogotes , limestone mounds sporadically climbing above the flat farmland below. The mounds peak over the haze like mountaintops until the mist dissipates. Verdant palm trees and brush carpet the mogotes . Between the treetops, red soil peeks through. Traditional thatched-roof homes stand alongside the expansive greenery of tobacco fields. The aromas of fresh coconut and pineapple overtake the earthy scent of the soil. The day is yours to explore the sensational landscape of the region, from the rugged karsts to the hidden caves. The hiking routes around Vinales are numerous, leading around farmsteads and into the labyrinths of cave networks. Alongside the trail, oxen pull plows through the fields. Farmers puff on thick homemade cigars. After over six miles, you reach La Cueva de Palmarito. A guide lights up a flashlight and leads you into the dark expanse. Stalactites decorate the ceiling and stalagmites rise out of the damp floor. An underground swimming hole fills the end of the walking route. The water has a depth of nearly 10 feet. Subtle droplets drip from the cave ceiling into the water. In the darkness, you can’t see the ripples, but you can hear the intermittent drops.

dayInfo.title: Soroa – Cigars and Rainbows
dayInfo.description: In the morning, you can take in the sunrise at a premier eco-community. The elevated area provides a magnificent view of three distinct valleys. The sunrise bathes the panorama in a light pink hue. Members of the community grow their own coffee and roast the beans in the morning light. The aroma itself is enough of a reason to make the journey. Venture to the nearby cigar factory in Pinar del Rio for a deeper look what it takes to make the famed Cuban cigars. After the tobacco is harvested, it is shipped to local factories to produce the majority of the work. The factory in Pinar del Rio is one of the smallest, with only 58 cigar rollers present at one time. The aroma of dried leaves is prevalent in the structure. A wooden rail separates you from the workers, allowing you to view their movement as they can focus on their work. Across the street is a cigar store known for its relaxing atmosphere, quality, and selection, including offering the cigars you watched the workers roll in front of your very eyes, such as a Romeo y Julieta. You continue to Soroa, which is often called the “Rainbow of Cuba.”

dayInfo.title: Soroa – Entering the Rainbow
dayInfo.description: The Sierra del Rosario Biosphere Reserve was declared a UNESCO site in the 1980s. It covers an area of 65,942 acres. After breakfast, you venture out into the marvelous landscape with a guide in search of the flora and fauna endemic to the region. Your guide quickly points into the trees at a bletia purpurea, a pine pink orchid. The flower blossoms with three to five light green leaves and an average of 41 flowers changing from white to pink, and a gold crest on the petals’ lip. The orchid is the symbol of the reservation. The scent of blooming nature emanates from the rich, diverse soil. Tocoros chirp in the canopy. Bee hummingbirds flutter their wings around freshly opened flowers. Woodpeckers tap at the tree bark in search of a morning meal. You follow the trail until you can hear the crashing sound of Salto de Soroa, an 820-foot waterfall. A small pool swells from the splashing cascade. The water is cool on your fingertips. The rainbow rises out of the waterfall’s mist cast by the multiple beading streams and gives the region its moniker.

dayInfo.title: Trinidad – Remnants of the CIA
dayInfo.description: In the morning, you can hear the calls of the Tocoro. Their bodies emerge from the emerald canopy with iridescent blue plumage along their neck and head. Today you make your way to the stunning colonial town of Trinidad, stopping at Bahia Cochinos along the way, better known to American’s as the “Bay of Pigs.” The inlet on the Gulf of Cazones is famous as the home of the failed CIA-sponsored attempt to overthrow Fidel Castro in 1961. When you arrive on the coast, it is hard to see the region as anything but beautiful. Powdery bleached sand runs into the various blue shades of the Caribbean Sea. The breeze rustles the palm fronds lining the beach. A museum commemorates the invasion. Photos almost overflow throughout the exhibits, creating an ambiance of importance. The 1,300 strong force made up of exiled Cuban’s landed on the beach and immediately faced the Cuban army. One of the most memorable artifacts in the gallery is the Brigade 2506 flag, which President John F. Kennedy held during a speech in 1962 when welcoming survivors of the battle back to Miami.

dayInfo.title: Trinidad – The Colonial Age of Cuba
dayInfo.description: Trinidad is a city of historic beauty set in its preserved colonial structures and antique atmosphere. Horses clop down the cobblestone streets. Red-tiled rooftops slope down covering the facades of pastel colored homes. The Spanish founded the city in the 16th century. It acted as the center for gold mining and farming until becoming the hub for sugar production in the 19th century. Mansions once owned by sugar barons continue to line the city streets. Plaza Mayor stands at the heart of Old Town. Palm trees cast thin shade over the cobbled street and paved walkways. The cafes near the center provide relaxing space to grab a refreshing drink and listen to inspiring music. Wrought iron fences enclose blossoming gardens near the pastel-yellow Palacio Cantero, which houses the Municipal History Museum. The 19th-century mansion contains Italian marble floors and large open rooms displaying documents and maps of Trinidad rise through the colonial ages to the bustling sugar economy. A steep spiral staircase leads up the tower, providing a panoramic view of the glowing city in the sunlight. You can see all the way to the Caribbean Sea and notice the way the layers of indigo color the water.

dayInfo.title: Trinidad – The Choices of Trinidad
dayInfo.description: In the morning, people choose to ride their bike to Playa Ancon. The eight-mile road takes people along the colonial homes, through a brief stretch of countryside, and to the winding edges of the white sand beach. Rolling jade mountains roll along the horizon in the background with the quiet waves crashing against the shoreline in the foreground. Today you discover the treasures in and around Trinidad. A vintage steam train travels between town and the Agabama Valley, home to the remains of the vibrant sugar mills and plantations. Adventurers seek out the cool climate and hidden coffee bushes of the Escambray Mountains. In the 1800s, more than 11,000 slaves helped till and power the 56 sugar mills around the city. Many of the slaves were taken from Africa’s west coast. Their beliefs and traditions followed them to the shores of Cuba. Trinidad boasts the most vibrant connection to the Afro-Cuban heritage with murals of orishas (saints) decorating private homes. Santeria blends Roman Catholicism with Yoruba beliefs. An authentic sanctuary has a mural of the moon and sun at different phases. The aroma of incense fills the gallery. Your guide introduces you to a priest who explains the importance of the images in the religion. The shrine awakens with energy. The goddess of the oceans stands on a pedestal overseeing her followers. A garden stands beyond the shrine. Light streams in from the windows and reflects off a carafe of water, blending sunlight and shadows.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Between Trinidad and Havana
dayInfo.description: Today you depart from the quiet colonial streets of Trinidad and make your way back to the musical cafes and rambunctious neighborhoods of Havana. En route, you stop at the bayside city of Cienfuegos. The French founded the city in 1819, shaping the white-pearled buildings with red-tiled roofs. The bay sparkles against the bleached edifices rising above the water. A gazebo stands at the center of Parque Jose Marti. A small Arch of Triumph erected in the early 20th century stands at the western end of the square. Castillo de Jagua, a preserved colonial fortress watches over the entrance of the bay as it has since the 18th century. A drawbridge continues to link the castle to the mainland, crossing the now-dried moat. A museum details the rich history of the fortress and its powerful defense against pirate attack. Outside of the city, a small forest surrounds Laguna Guanaroca. The reflective water resembles glass in its place nature. Herons and pelicans perch in the mangrove trees. Near the bustling leaves on the opposite side of the lagoon, you can see the pink plumage and elegant necks of a flock of flamingoes. The bustle of the city has disappeared, replaced by the flapping wings of graceful flamingoes as they settle into a new spot on the water.

dayInfo.title: Havana – The Brightside of Havana
dayInfo.description: If you wake up early in the morning and walk along the Malecón, you feel as though you have the entire city to yourself. The water continues to lap against the lower reaches of the seawall. The outlines of the defensive fortresses at the mouth of Havana Bay change to imposing stone structures. Classic cars return to cruising down the street. Artists open up the warehouse on Port Avenue. The 19th-century space houses a collection of painters, wood carvers, weavers, and crafts-people shaping the image of everyday life in Havana. Paintings of Che Guevara are displayed next to hand-carved bongos. After breakfast, your private transfer meets you at the hotel. You say goodbye to Havana with one last lingering glance before transferring to Jose Marti International Airport for your flight home.

tourName: Best of Cuba Tour in Seven Days
placesVisited: Havana, Vinales, Cienfuegos, Trinidad, Cayo Macho, Santa Clara
generalInfo: Witness fine cigars rolled before your eyes and a majestic waterfall hidden in the Escambray Mountains during your 7-day Cuba tour immersing you in the island’s heart and soul. French architecture and Cuban heroes decorate Cienfuegos. The forest canopy protects radiant hummingbirds. Classic American cars add to the soundtrack of Havana. Cuba provides endless excitement and tangible splendor gathered into your week-long adventure filled with an endlessly uplifting spirit.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Brilliance of Havana Style
dayInfo.description: Step off the plane at Jose Marti International Airport and meet your private transfer at customs to reach the heart of classic Havana. Pastel-colored buildings travel alongside the road reminding you of Cuba’s Caribbean setting. The University of Havana dates back to Dominican monks in the 18th century and stairs lead to the neoclassical 20th-century structures of the Vedado district. Once in your comfortable accommodations in the heart of Old Havana, you can settle into the colonial buildings and energetic music that fill the streets.

dayInfo.title: Vinales – The Secret Beauty of Vinales
dayInfo.description: You will leave behind Havana’s charm in the morning with your private transfer traveling along the city’s seaside Malecon. Classic American cars cruise beside the seawall before the highway shifts to a country road and the spectacular view of Vinales Valley. Red soil will spread across the plain with intermittent limestone karsts rising out of the valley like mounds. You can travel along the paths meandering around the karsts’ basins and possibly find a farmer tilling his field with two gigantic oxen to pull an antique metal plow and giving you an insider’s look at how Cubans cultivate tobacco. Return to Havana for the evening.

dayInfo.title: Cienfuegos – Visiting History
dayInfo.description: Locals roast homegrown coffee beans in the morning with the scent possibly lingering around Vinales’s main street. After a leisurely morning, you will leave Havana for Cienfuegos and views of the Atlantic Ocean. A very charming city, you can explore the El Nicho Waterfalls, take a tour of the Palacio de Valle or simply settle into your accommodations and enjoy the views. Sunsets in Cienfuegos can be very dramatic, so you will end your day positioned to celebrate the beauty of it all.

dayInfo.title: Trinidad – Tradition of Music
dayInfo.description: In the morning, you can step out onto the streets of Cienfuegos to find turquoise water shining against the city’s white facades and the 18th-century Castillo de Jagua fortress standing guard against the bay. Your private transfer will take to the colonial town of Trinidad. The sounds of clopping horse hooves may echo down the cobblestones of the car-less city center beneath the pastel yellow bell tower of the former Convent of Saint Francisco de Asis. At the Casa de la Musica, you can hear musicians play traditional Cuban music celebrating their heritage and the city’s large Afro-Cuban culture.

dayInfo.title: Trinidad – A Look at Trinidad’s Borders
dayInfo.description: Fragments of sugar mills will speckle Valle de los Ingenios outside of Trinidad. An antique steam train will travel between the city and the former valley harboring the wealth of sugar barons and Cuba’s natural beauty. In the Escambray Mountains, you can board a former Russian military vehicle to Codina National Park in search of Cuba’s national bird, blossoming orchids, and the 203-foot waterfall Salto del Caburni splashing into jade pools with cold, refreshing water.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Part of the Revolution
dayInfo.description: When you arrive in Santa Clara, the spirit of the revolution remains tangible. The university encourages students to question authority, based on the ideals of Che Guevara. The local tobacco factory produces some of Cuba’s finest cigars, including Che Guevara’s favorite. Upon your return to Havana, you can embark on a tour led by a local architect. The powerful dome of the capitol will crown the cityscape. Cobblestone streets in Cathedral Square with Baroque and neoclassical facades will accentuate the city’s splendor. After your tour, your private dance instructor will show you the soul of Cuba by teaching you salsa.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Close Your Eyes and Remember
dayInfo.description: At a glance, the grandeur of the Palacio de los Capitanes remains prominent as it borders the Plaza de Armas. The elegance of the palace, along with its history, has shaped the splendor of Havana’s culture. After breakfast, your private transfer will meet you at your accommodation. Soon you will return to Jose Marti International Airport to check-in for your flight, but you can take your time in the morning to enjoy one last stroll around the magnificent streets of Old Havana.

tourName: Cuban Culture and Heritage: Havana to the Bay of Pigs
placesVisited: Havana, Cienfuegos, Trinidad, Bay of Pigs
generalInfo: If you fancy a chance to immerse yourself in Cuban culture and heritage that spans Havana to the Bay of Pigs, then this eight-day tour of Cuba’s best destinations is perfectly suited to you. Discover old-world charm in Cuba’s vibrant capital, dance to Afro-Cuban music at chic bars in Cienfuegos, appreciate the local flavors of Trinidad, and admire the untamed beauty of the Bay of Pigs during your adventure.

dayInfo.title: Havana - Discover Cuba’s 16th-Century Charm
dayInfo.description: Colonial Spanish charm, diverse artistic expression, and a bohemian atmosphere dominate Cuba’s capital city, Havana. Here, laughter pours from chic cafés while you unravel the history of 16th-century landmarks and move to the rhythms of Afro-Cuban music at dance halls dotting the cityscape. You will arrive, meet your transfer, drop off your belongings at your accommodation, and set off for lunch and a panoramic tour of Cuba’s capital. You will begin near the administrative buildings of Plaza de la Revolución, amble down the lush boulevard of Quinta Avenida, explore Malecón esplanade, and the Necrópolis Cristóbal Colón this afternoon.

dayInfo.title: Havana - Captivating Culture in the Capital
dayInfo.description: Old Havana is action-packed and overflowing with Cuban culture. After breakfast, you will tour the UNESCO heritage site to discover what makes Havana tick. Baroque and neoclassical architecture dress Old Havana’s districts, pastel-colored buildings juxtapose the concrete, and classic cars cruise stylishly around town. You will explore Havana Cathedral’s sanctified structure, saunter down Obispo Street to visit charming boutiques, and sip cocktails at Ernest Hemingway’s watering hole, La Bodeguita Del Medio. You will then visit Hemingway’s home and see where he wrote some of his famous works, as well as pop in to the Fábrica de Arte Cubano, a trendy club cum art gallery.

dayInfo.title: Havana - Devour Cojímar’s Best Delicacies
dayInfo.description: You will wake up and ponder a day of delightful adventure ahead, tucking into breakfast early in the morning in anticipation of experiences set to enchant. Afterward, transfer eastbound from Havana to the coastal fishing village of Cojímar and see what Hemingway saw when he wrote The Old Man and the Sea . The Straits of Florida teem with marine life and fishermen take their catches to local markets, where restaurateurs source mouthwatering fresh fish. Today, a culinary tour around Cojímar will combine the best of Cuba’s seafood and agricultural produce as you tuck into several traditional delicacies at endearing eateries.

dayInfo.title: Trinidad - Contemplate Cienfuegos’ Colonial History
dayInfo.description: You will enjoy a brilliant breakfast, pack your bags, and transfer across the Cuban countryside to Cienfuegos this morning. Here, colonial-era buildings command attention, gold-leaf mosaics and immaculate frescoes veil the walls and ceilings of cultural centers, and the sheltered Cienfuegos Bay shares spectacular backdrops for scenic photography. You will wander Paseo El Prado, the longest street in Cuba, and absorb the history that emanates from the area’s colonial constructions. In the afternoon you will continue to your next destination, the UNESCO heritage-awarded town of Trinidad in central Cuba.

dayInfo.title: Trinidad - Embrace Views of the Escambray Mountains
dayInfo.description: Today you will enjoy Trinidad’s unique allure. Cobblestone streets connect the plazas and authentic restaurants line narrow alleys. Church bells ring from the Convent of San Francisco de Asis and museums reflect the colonial history that influenced the town. In the afternoon you will visit the agricultural sugar cane plantations that blanket the hills of Guachinango. Views of the Escambray mountain range on the horizon from Valle de los Ingenios, or Valley of the Sugar Mills, are particularly impressive. At night you will follow the calls of rumba drums to the Plaza Mayor and salsa to the sultry music.

dayInfo.title: Bay of Pigs - Uncover Cuba’s Historic Bay
dayInfo.description: One cannot visit Cuba without experiencing the dramatic events of the Bay of Pigs. But instead of recounting history through museum exhibits and galleries, visitors are rewarded with some of the most spectacular coastal experiences in Cuba. You will spend some time pondering the area’s past when you arrive and then settle into your accommodation around the corner from the bay’s breathtaking beaches and rugged coast. During your stay at the Bay of Pigs, you can freely explore the postcard-perfect inlet and partake in many magnificent marine adventures.

dayInfo.title: Bay of Pigs - Spectacular Snorkeling and Scuba Diving
dayInfo.description: Days in the Bay of Pigs are best left open to explore the area’s untamed natural beauty at your preferred pace. After an indulgent Cuban breakfast you may make your way to the pristine beaches and rocky headlands to swim in the sapphire sea. Marine adventures can take you offshore to sensational snorkeling and scuba-diving spots. During these experiences, you can get up close and personal with the magnificent marine life beneath the water’s surface. You may spot barracuda, lionfish, groupers, and more as you float around the coral, caverns, and coves.

dayInfo.title: Bay of Pigs - Cuba’s Wildlife Viewing Wonderland
dayInfo.description: On the final morning of your Cuban cultural adventure, you may wander to the town of Playa Giron after breakfast and explore the flourishing forests that fringe the coastline. This is a perfect opportunity to capture stunning wildlife photography and make a few more magical memories before you leave the enchanting country. Be sure to keep your eyes peeled for hummingbirds, owls, wrens, sparrows, woodpeckers, and hawks. Afterward, you will collect your things and transfer to the airport, where you will begin your journey back home.

tourName: Enchanting Sites & Sounds of Cuba Tour: From Colonial Towns to Salsa Rhythms
placesVisited: Havana, Guama, Caleta Buena, Cienfuegos, Trinidad, Santa Clara, Las Terrazas, Vinales Valley
generalInfo: Cuba makes you want to dance into the night, experiencing the entertainment and living history inside the cities and searching for colorful flora and fauna protected in the national parks. Locals laugh as they jump into the Atlantic Ocean near the waterside avenue of the Malecón. A Tocororo twitters in the jade forest canopy. Flamingoes catch your eye against the waters of a quiet lagoon. Guitarists and bongo players fill the streets with passionate songs from sunrise to well past midnight. Your custom tailored tour shows you the exciting life of Cuba, which at times feels like worlds away and years apart.

dayInfo.title: Havana – At First Glance
dayInfo.description: Havana is a city easily conjured in dreams. However, the streets and the people quickly exceed expectations. Your flight lands at Jose Marti International Airport, where you have your first look of the city. The airport already transports you to a different time, absent of wifi and long distance phone calls. Locals gather around the exit, holding up signs for old friends and returning family members. Your private transfer greets you at the baggage claim and escorts you into the city. Outside of the airport, ankle-high grass ripples in the breeze. Fresh murals celebrating the Cuban socialist spirit decorate dilapidated walls. The contemporary high-rises of Vedado overlook the renovated colonial architecture of Old Havana. The aroma of the ocean drifts over the walls along the Malecón, the seaside avenue. You settle into your hotel, located in the heart of the antique city. Classic American cars park outside the columned arcades of Hotel Inglaterra, a 19th-century neoclassical edifice standing opposite the elegant walkway of the Paseo del Prado.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Indulging in an Image
dayInfo.description: In the morning, teenagers make their way to a quiet outcropping of stones beyond the sea wall of the Malecón. They strip to their boxers and jump into the refreshing water of the Atlantic Ocean. Occasional spurts of mist splash onto the walkway from the waves crashing against the stones. After breakfast, your guide meets you at the hotel with a classic car waiting outside. The automobiles in the city harken back to a time just before the trade embargo between the United States and Cuba. Mechanics work overtime trying to tinker with antique parts or create new components out of local, handy objects. You step into a restored Chevrolet with white leather interior and white and pink exterior. Traveling in the convertible lets the wind comb through your hair. Locals wave to you as you venture to Plaza de Revolucion. A 59-foot tall statue of Jose Marti, the father of Cuban independence, adorns the staircase. Behind him rises a nearly 360-foot tall tower overlooking the five square mile area plaza. Visitors often take pictures of the silhouetted statues of Che Guevara and Camilo Cienfuegos outlining the buildings opposite the tower. The car drops you off near Cathedral Square where your tour of Old Havana begins.

dayInfo.title: Guama – Cuba Crocodile Country
dayInfo.description: At sunrise, fishermen stroll along the Malecón, resting their poles on their shoulders. They stand along the sea wall and cast their line into the water. The imposing Morro Castle frames the bay to the fishermen’s east. After breakfast, your private transfer greets you at the hotel and leads you to your first day out of Havana, taking you to Guama and the ecological reserve of Cienaga de Zapata. The region takes its name from the Taino chief who made his last stand against the Spanish in Baracoa in the 16th century. You step aboard a small boat to travel through the mangrove-lined canals leading you to Treasure Lake. A recreation of a Taino village stands on the opposite side. Emerald trees shade the thatched-roofed huts. Sculptures depict the daily life of the aboriginal culture. Numerous cone-shaped huts look over the gentle swells of the lake. One of the locals climbs a palm tree and tosses down a coconut. Your guide opens the fruit with four quick hits of a machete before giving you the gourd to drink. At the crocodile farm, the breeder explains that in the 1960s, a program was developed to protect he marsh-dwelling crocodiles, which at the time were almost extinct. Your guide provides a cultural demonstration on how the original inhabitants of the swamplands hunted the reptiles with a bow. Breeders take you along the expanse of the park to show the various sizes of the crocodiles and even provide a feeding presentation.

dayInfo.title: Cienfuegos – Witnessing Cuban Variety
dayInfo.description: You have quickly learned that Cuba is more than classic cars and mojitos. Today your guide leads you through the trails of Zapata Swamp Park in search of some of Cuba’s most famous avifauna. The more than 1,600 square-mile area encompasses 175 species of birds, 31 types of reptiles, and over 900 plant species. The flat land contains basins to the Hatiguanico and Hanabana Rivers. Parakeets twitter in the canopy. Their almost-fluorescent green plumage stands out from the emerald leaves. Your guide points to a nearby tree. The Tocororo, Cuba’s national bird, perches on a small branch. Their back plumage radiates iridescent blue and green. Their crown is colored a dark blue with their breast bright white. In the lake, a flock of red flamingos stands tall. Their vibrant feathers reflect in the serene rippling water. Their black beaks protrude from their thin, graceful necks. After your exploration of the reserve, you make your way to the Bay of Pigs to see the small museum commemorating the historical conflict that set the tone of American-Cuban relations.

dayInfo.title: Trinidad – Picking Up the Pearl
dayInfo.description: In the morning, the sun washes over the white facades and red-tiled roofs of Cienfuegos. The charm of the city has earned it the title of the “Pearl of the South.” The French settled the city in the 19th century and designed the streets and surrounding architecture with seductive beauty alongside the glistening bay. Horses pull carriages down the paved streets and near the Malecón. The silver-gray hue of Palacio de Gobierno dominates the southern edge of Parque Marit. Through the front door, you can glimpse at the palatial main staircase winding upwards to the second story. The Teatro Tomas Terry shares both French and Italian influences and was erected in the 19th century. The auditorium holds 950 seats. Hand-carved Cuban hardwoods complement the Carrara marble accents. The frescoes decorating the ceiling create a playful ambiance in the majestic of the gallery. At the mouth of the bay, you can see the 18th-century fortress of Castillo de Jagua continuing to protect the city from pirates and privateers. After lunch, you venture to the sleepy colonial town of Trinidad. The city feels more like a time capsule taking you back into the bygone era of sugar barons and cobblestone streets.

dayInfo.title: Trinidad – Finding Trinidad
dayInfo.description: The streets of Trinidad are a treasure to themselves. Pastel painted homes stand beneath red-tiled roofs. Music emanates from cafes, and small brick buildings locals use as social clubs. The Escambray Mountains border the city to the north, and the Caribbean Sea edges Trinidad to the south. Horses clop down the narrow streets near the historic city center. The day is yours to enjoy Trinidad as you please. Stroll along the walkways and the neo-baroque structures of Plaza Mayor to see the small square of Plazuela El Jigue. Travel by antique steam train to visit Valle do los Ingenios, home to the ruins of 19th-century sugarcane plantations. Troubadours jam with traditional songs and Afro-Cuban spirit at the Casa de la Musica. Vintage lamps and café tables line the stairway. People sip cuba libres, engage in passionate conversation and let the music move them. Near Casa de la Trova stands the open-air market known for its vendors who sell handcrafted textiles and crochet work. The musical instruments, including the hand-carved bongos, have colorful artwork decorating the smooth wood. Strolling through the market immerses you in the sensibilities of the city, providing a window into the way locals view art, music, and the culture of Trinidad.

dayInfo.title: Santa Clara – Nature and the Revolution
dayInfo.description: In the morning, you wave goodbye to Trinidad and venture into the Escambray Mountains to discover Topes de Collante Nature Reserve. A 6x6 former Russian military vehicle meets you at the entrance. The engine roars as the caterpillar-like mobile trudges up the rugged terrain. The tallest peak in the range rises to a height of 3,740 feet above sea level. The winds sweep in from the Atlantic Ocean on the north side of the mountains. Fauna and avifauna find refuge in the ferns, banana trees, and jasmine. Hike through the coffee plantations to view the budding grains on the branches. Thatched roofs frame traditional farmer’s houses. The Caburni River trundles over the cliffs more than 200 feet down to a series of ponds. Your guide leads you along the path to a natural pool. The jade water bubbles beneath the red limestone walls bordering the pond. A small waterfall cascades into the edges of the pool, refilling the area with cold, fresh water. Cuba is abundant with endless discovery, from the large fanning fronds of tropical trees to the empowering monument of Che Guevara in the town of Santa Clara. The town hosts the most prestigious university outside of Havana. The rebellious spirit captured in the artistic representations of the guerilla leader spreads throughout the streets and university classrooms. A bronze 22-foot statue crowns the square.

dayInfo.title: Las Terrazas – Eco-Friendly Immersion
dayInfo.description: Today, your private transfer escorts you from central Cuba to western Cuba, passing Havana to settle in the eco-community of Las Terrazas. You pass a large complex overlooking the water outside of Havana. You think it’s the start of a new community project, but in fact, it is a celebrated medical school known as the Latin American School of Medicine. The World Health Organization, along with the Medical Board of California, recognizes the quality and accreditation of the school. The complex can accommodate more than 19,500 students from more than 110 countries. You travel down narrow rural roads, sharing the street with horse-drawn buggies and tractors. When you arrive in Las Terrazas, the lush jade canopy of the rainforest blankets the hillside. The community has taken it upon itself to reforest the area after the devastating deforestation in the 1950s. The small community was built in the heart of the 61,776-acre Sierra del Rosario Biosphere Reserve. Trekking trails meander alongside the serene lake. An artist’s studio overlooks the gentle water. Locals take out rowboats painted with pastel colors. A restored coffee plantation outside of town combines contemporary ingenuity with the lavish grounds of a 19th-century boom. You can follow a guide to the treetops and soar like a bee hummingbird through the trees on a zipline excursion. Take in the unparalleled view of the reserve and search for blossoming orchids along the high, jungle branches.

dayInfo.title: Las Terrazas – Vision of Vinales
dayInfo.description: Descend the dizzying road to the valley where you find a piney aroma emanating from the lush farmland. You have left Las Terrazas behind for the red soiled landscape shaded by towering palm trees. Intermittent limestone karsts rise above the farmland like gigantic mounds. Black piglets run around the edges of the farmhouse. The farmer guides a large metal plow pulled by two large oxen across the field. The tobacco grows firm and tasty around the region of Pinar del Rio. Your guide points out the fibers of the leaves, calling them the fat of the tobacco, which provides the flavor. Inside the drying house, you find rows of leaves drying naturally underneath the thatched roof frame. The farmer explains the best way to clean the leaves after they are dried to ensure the natural oils and fibers are efficiently burned. The leaves absorb the flavor of the elements. The farmer passes around the leaves for you to inhale their natural aroma. He sits down on a small bench and places a wooden plank on his lap. A regular sized cigar takes three leaves. The farmer strips the leave lengthwise and spreads it out along the wooden plank to create the filler. The filler is the heart of the cigar. The farmer then cuts both sides to mark the cigar size, placing the filler atop the binding leaf before rolling the leaves tightly together, using water streaks to seal the cigar. Continue to Vinales to enjoy a panoramic view of the valley before returning to Havana. Before dinner, you meet with a local instructor to celebrate your time in the city by learning to dance salsa like a local.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Unique Union
dayInfo.description: The lights of Vedado shine over the city like stars before sunrise. In the morning, the sun washes over the high-rises of the contemporary district bringing the historic colonial buildings of Old Town to a modern perspective. Cuba’s National Union of Writers has a base in a colonial mansion located in the Vedado district. An outdoor terrace begins to bustle with intellectuals, musicians, and writers of all ages. Some of Cuba’s best-known singers perform a variety of musical styles in the courtyard, blending bolero with trova while the old guard sips mojitos. The mixture of contemporary and classic architecture displays the diversity of the neighborhood and reminds you of Cuba’s far-reaching beauty. Today, your private transfer meets you at the hotel when you’re ready and escorts you to Jose Marti International Airport for your flight home.

tourName: Ernest Hemingway Cuba Tour: Following in the Footsteps of a Legend
placesVisited: Havana
generalInfo: This custom tailored tour retraces the steps of Ernest Hemingway, giving you access to the unique, eclectic cultures of the Caribbean country brimming with rich soil and surrounded by the immaculate sea. The architecture and gregarious people of Cuba speak to a rich legacy spanning centuries. Dancing and music enrich every day. The sweet aromas of coconut and pineapple emanate from gardens and markets. Coffee trees grow lush and strong. Ernest Hemingway’s former home maintains an inspiring ambiance. Murals decorate the streets. Artwork acts as a form of urban expression. Spanish colonial influences shape contemporary life, creating the distinctive character of Cuba.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Inspiring Images of Havana
dayInfo.description: Havana is a city of music and vitality. Your plane descends into the airport providing an aerial view of the thin wafting palm trees and tall tropical grass swaying in the breeze. You meet your private transfer at baggage claim eager to enter the famous charms of the city. Classic cars move past you down the boulevard leading into the heart of the city. You pass the tall spire adorning the Plaza de Revolucion. The square measures more than 775,000 square feet. The Jose Marti Memorial features the 358-foot star shaped tower casting a shadow over the grounds. The nearly 60-foot statue of depicts the Cuban national hero in thought. A mural of Che Guevara adorns the concrete building on the northern edge of the square. The University of Havana was established in the Vedado district in the 18th century, as one of the first universities founded in the Americas. The stairway leads from the street to the portico, creating a neoclassical ambiance. A statue in front of the university entrance depicts a woman welcoming students onto the grounds above the words, “Alma Mater,” which is in reference to how a school is meant to nourish students through education. The sounds of crashing waves along the sea walls known as the Malecón fade beneath the bands performing salsa along the pedestrian street of Calle Obispo. Set into the vibrancy of Old Havana, enjoying the welcoming ambiance.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Embracing the Culture
dayInfo.description: Horse drawn carriages stand along the edges of Parque Central. When the horses trot down the cobblestone streets, the sound of their clopping hooves echoes off of the stone buildings. Chevys painted pearl white and bright pink cruise past Hotel Inglaterra, the oldest hotel in Cuba, which was established in the 1870s. Winston Churchill once enjoyed the comforts inside the neoclassical façade. Begin your day with an intriguing conversation with a university professor specializing in contemporary Cuba. Your conversation pulls from the visual distinction between the historically renovated buildings of Old Havana, contrasting the facades of the colonial buildings in Centro Habana, the edging district. The architecture creates a visual ambiance, but part of the city’s charm is the eclectic culture. Your guide leads you to the cobblestone alley of Callejón de Hamel. Murals, ceramics, and statues create a colorful and inviting outdoor exhibit emphasizing the characteristics of the Afro-Cuban culture. The sounds of rumba emanate from the ends of the street. The band begins to play. Dancers swing their hips. Their movements tell tales of the culture through Cuban history, from the slave trade to Cuban integration in the 1950s. The dancing accentuates the bright art filled with images of community figures and deities, including the prowling leopard, known for its connecting to the secret fraternal society Abakuá .

dayInfo.title: Havana – The Heart in Work
dayInfo.description: The aroma of fresh pineapple emanates from breakfast. Juicy, yellow pieces of the fruit offer morning refreshment in the tropical climate. Brass lions catch the sunlight stretching over Paseo de Marti. Historic mansions continue to rise above the sidewalks on either end of the boulevard. An elevated pedestrian walkway divides the two sides of the street. Marble benches and brass gas lamps provide insight into Havana’s decadent past. Local artists display their work and gain inspiration from the daily life of cityscape, along with the schoolchildren resting in the shade. After breakfast, you venture to a cooperative known for its work in embroidery and handcrafts. Women stitch together elegant designs, turning shawls, shirts, and table-runners into works of art. They move with grace and speed, paying close attention to every detail. Continue to an organic farm, situated in a large garden outside the old city. Cuba’s urban agriculture provides up to 70 percent of the fruits and vegetables consumed in the country’s larger cities. A large lime tree grows at the edge of the two-acre farm. The aroma adds a tart, zesty quality to the air. Rows of vegetables create a serene reprieve from the endless activity of Havana. Relax in the slower pace and peaceful ambiance of the farm, along with the popular restaurant located on the property. Return to Old Havana before dinner to engage with local students about the daily Cuban experience.

dayInfo.title: Pinar del Rio – Majesty of Pinar del Rio
dayInfo.description: Your private transfer drives along the Malecón, leading you outside of town en route to Pinar del Rio. The Caribbean Sea splashes against the city walls spraying mist onto the walkway. Morro Castle disappears behind the intermittent high-rises of the more modern neighborhood Western Havana. Men stand atop the sea walls and cast their lines into the water for a relaxed search for fish. Your guide points out the Marina Hemingway, the largest marina in Cuba with an ability to hold up to 400 vessels. Pastel homes line the canals. Ship masts tower over the rooftops resembling thin, leafless trees. Outside of the city, you stop at an organic farm known for growing its own coffee beans. The community also opened a coffeehouse on the premises. The area promotes artistic expression, teaching various skills, and promoting the values of community in the form of land cultivation. Local children and teens fill the artistic space located in the open-air wood-frame structure covered with a thatched roof. Sip a freshly brewed cup of coffee, visit with the enthusiastic artists, and bask in the tropical countryside before continuing to Pinar del Rio, the center of Cuba’s tobacco plantations.

dayInfo.title: Pinar del Rio – Cigars and Mogotes
dayInfo.description: Your day begins at a local tobacco farm for insight into the famous cigars of Cuba, from cultivation to production. Stroll through the fields to see the tobacco plants with their large leaves rustling in the breeze. Enter the drying house, where the leaves dangle from posts waiting for their time to be rolled. Floral and mineral aromas fill the room. The leaves turn from emerald to beige. After your tour, the farmer leads you into a room filled with dried leaves offering to roll a cigar fresh, keen to teach you the process along the way. Take a seat beside the farmer, roll out the leaf, and follow the step-by-step process in producing a freshly rolled Cuban cigar. Roll the cigar next to your ear and listen for a slight crinkle. Make sure no extra tobacco falls out of the edges. Enjoy the earthy aroma of the outer wrapping. These are the three main techniques of ensuring you have found a quality cigar. Continue to the dramatic landscape of the Vinales Valley. Farms fill in the spaces between the mogotes , karsts with rounded tops. Horses travel along the trails connecting networks of caves honeycombing the rock formations. The Mural of Prehistory drapes across nearly 400 feet of a 2,200-foot tall mountain, depicting the large snails, dinosaurs, sea monsters, and humans.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Differences in Community
dayInfo.description: In the morning, you can hear the sound of the horses pulling carts filled with produce down the streets. Sugarcane stalks and large pineapple form mounds as you move across the town. The Francisco Donatien factory stands in the heart of Pinar del Rio. What was once an antique prison transformed into a premier cigar producer for the country in the 1960s, and opening up to world production in the 1990s. Your guide takes you through the factory along a walkway guarded by a wooden rail, separating you from the factory floor. You find a similar aroma as the drying house is on the farm. The workers roll the cigars with quick movements, relying as much on instinct as instruction. You venture outside of Pinar del Rio to the town of Las Terrazas, an eco-village settled in the late 1960s. The biosphere has gained UNESCO recognition, along with maintaining Cuba’s earliest surviving coffee plantations from the 18th century. The town encourages the interaction between people of the area and visitors to form cultural understanding. A canopy tour takes you 82 feet above the ground, racing from platform to platform set in the woodlands and leading to the boathouse more than 2,600 feet away on the edge of the lake. The wind blows against your cheeks. You can hear the sounds of birds chirping in the trees and see the colorful blossoming orchid petals in the canopy. The platforms provide an unparalleled view of the entire eco-reserve, from the plantations to the rivers.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Havana Classics
dayInfo.description: The sounds of Havana welcome you back to the city. The vibrant music and historic architecture create a nostalgic atmosphere. The morning sun highlights the elegant Havana Cathedral. Blocks of coral from the Gulf of Mexico add to the textured exterior of the Baroque façade. After breakfast, you make your way to the Museo de Ernesto Hemingway, located in the suburb of San Francisco de Paula. The writer’s home, known as La Finca Vigia, the lookout farm, has a Moorish-style on 15 acres of land, providing a view of the bright sea on the horizon. Hemingway wrote nine novels while living in Cuba, including one of his most famous titles, For Whom the Bell Tolls. Hemingway’s Royal typewriter stands propped up on a bookshelf in his bedroom, where he wrote standing up every morning. Spanish bullfighting posters adorn the walls, along with trophies from African safaris, and even a ceramic bowl fashioned by Pablo Picasso. Return to Havana for a tour of the Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes. The rationalist-style of the architecture contributes to the atmosphere shaped by Cuban Art spanning the centuries, from the 1600s to the present.

dayInfo.title: Havana – The Grandeur of Character
dayInfo.description: One of the world’s largest opera houses faces the trotting horses and refurbished Cadillacs parked at the edges of Parque Central in Havana. Belgian architect Paul Belau designed and erected the edifice in 1915 as part of a larger complex. The baroque façade features sculptures representing the allegories of benevolence, educations, music, and theater. The magnificent structure emphasizes Cuba’s connection to music of all kinds, whether in the form of celebratory sounds on the street or structured performances in historic buildings. The character of Cuba is complex and captivating, procuring elements of cultures from around the world, covering centuries. Today, your private transfer escorts you from your hotel to Jose Marti International Airport for your flight home. Your tour of Cuba may have ended but your connection with the people, the sites, and the heritage continues.

tourName: Heart & Soul of Cuba Tour: Discovering Its People and Culture
placesVisited: Havana, Cienfuegos, Trinidad, Bay of Pigs, Jaimanitas
generalInfo: Cuba is like a time capsule recently opened that is trying to restore its former majesty. The contrast of crumbling colonial architecture alongside freshly renovated façades adds to the allure of the cities. The culture has inspired artists to submerge entire neighborhoods in art projects. Ernest Hemingway captured a fishing village in an award-winning novel. The effects of the Cuban Revolutionary War have shaped everyday life. The slave trade of the 18th and 19th centuries led to the mesmerizing Afro-Cuban culture. Your custom-tailored tour immerses you into the heart and soul of the changing landscape of Cuba through the eyes of the locals.

dayInfo.title: Havana – An Artistic Welcome
dayInfo.description: Havana is a city of eclectic culture and captivating imagery. The ocean sprays against the edges of the Malecón, the seaside boulevard, splashing water over the wall. Old fortresses guard the bay and harken back to an era of pirates and privateers. High-rises tower over the neighborhood of Vedado, looking out to the historic architecture along the old harbor. Havana is a city of beautiful contrasts. Your private transfer meets you at Jose Marti International Airport and leads you on a brief driving tour of the city. Outside of the airport, you find state funded murals draping over thick walls imitating the colors of the Cuban flag. Tall emerald grass rises higher than people’s ankles. The suburbs of Havana highlight the pastel colors and tropical climate for which the Caribbean is known. Delving deeper into the center of the city takes you to the neighborhood of Muraleando, which harbors a community development project. Two art teachers have teamed up to teach local children about the importance of art. The children’s passion soon led to work spilling out of the classroom and onto the streets. Murals depict fanciful celebrations of Cuba, representing the culture and people in all walks of life. You have a chance to meet with artists who continue to teach classes in the community space, surrounded by the inspiration of Havana itself. The vibrant colors of the murals, along with the elaborate poses of the statues, accentuate the smiles of the children eager to share their experiences with you. You continue to Old Havana, where you settle into your hotel amidst the colonial charm of the district.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Eclectic Style of Havana
dayInfo.description: The Capitol building in Havana reaches a height of more than 300 feet. The dome was the tallest point in Havana until the 1950s. The morning sun washes over the city, bringing the dome back to light first and foremost. After breakfast, your guide meets you at the hotel, accompanied by an architect tasked with helping restore the antique buildings around the old city. Before you venture on a tour, you can sit down with the architect to discuss the challenges of the renovation of an entire district with roots dating back to the 16th century. Once outside, you take in the fabulous atmosphere of Old Havana. Musicians fill the street and serenade passersby with soothing guitar strums and pulsating bongo beats. Cobblestone streets meander around the district, leading beneath the lush trees of Central Park and along the energetic avenue of Calle Obispo. Plaza Vieja is the oldest square in Havana with roots dating back to the 16th-century Spanish settlement. Your guide paints a vivid picture of military ceremonies taking place at the center of the plaza surrounded by onlookers watching from the windows of the bordering mansions. At Callejon de Hamel, you are invited into the Afro-Cuban culture. Vivacious murals cover the walls depicting spiritual life and everyday activities. The rumba-like sounds emanate from the houses along the street. The community practices a Santeria, a combination of Catholic and African tribal traditions. Your guide points out a number of deities mixed into the imagery of the murals. The community is deeply engrained in Cuba’s history and yet also feels worlds apart.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Havana from All Angles
dayInfo.description: The Museum of the Revolution is located in the former Presidential Palace. The palace encompasses the grandeur and political corruption for which the revolution stood against. Tiffany and Co. of New York decorated the interior, embellishing the neoclassical elements. The Salon de los Espejos imitates the elaborate design of the Room of Mirrors at Versailles. Above the city, children retreat to their rooftops to cast their kites into the sea breeze. After breakfast, you meet with a professor from the University of Havana to discuss Cuba’s economic platform and its role on the global stage of social issues. For a unique view of Cuban culture, you make your way to the Cuban Baseball Hall of Fame, established in 1939. The museum honors players, managers, and umpires of pre-revolutionary Cuba. The year 2014 saw the first inductees into the Hall of Fame since 1961. You have a brief introduction into the passionate connection Cuba maintains with baseball, from watching children play stickball in the streets to the intensity of player training on the national team. The museum commemorates past inductees but also highlights the spirit of the game in Cuba. Men gather every day beneath the shade in Central Park to debate about pitchers, lineups, winners, losers, and the hottest new Cuban baseball talent.

dayInfo.title: Cienfuegos – Story of Cienfuegos
dayInfo.description: The city of Cienfuegos has French roots dating back to the 19th century. Red-tiled roofs accentuate the pearled hues of elegant structures. The indigo water of the bay sparkles against the clean image of the city with Castillo de Jagua lingering at the mouth of the harbor in the background. The graceful boulevard known as Paseo del Prado runs perpendicular to the Malecón. The large dome of the Government’s Palace casts a shadow of the Plaza de Armas. In the evening, poets tell tales and croon to couples snuggling up together along the sea wall. After you tour the streets, your guide introduces you to several cuentapropistas, self-employed workers. One woman has a cart filled with ripe bananas and sweet chilies. She freely talks about the private economy and her passion for growing or harvesting the produce to sell to those in the city. Her fresh perspective tells one of the many different stories of Cuban life in Cienfuegos. After lunch, you meet with students at a prestigious art school known for its talent. When you arrive, the students are eager to introduce themselves, along with their specialization in their studies. The dancers welcome you with a small performance. They use the movement from traditional Cuban dances, such as rumba and salsa, while adding their own special twists.

dayInfo.title: Cienfuegos – Colonial Captivation
dayInfo.description: The scenic drive to Trinidad takes you along the winding coastal road. The Escambray Mountains roll along the horizon north of Trinidad. The Caribbean Sea casts a turquoise gleam to the south of the city. You arrive in the preserved colonial charms of Trinidad and feel as though you have stepped back in time. Horses pull buggies along the cobblestone streets of the car-free historic center. Red-tile roofs swoop over pastel painted homes on the outskirts of the city. The bell tower of the Museum of Municipal History rises to meet the mountaintops in the distance. Follow your guide on a tour of the historic structures harkening back to the sugar boom of the 19th century and the affluence of the sugar barons. The yellow pastel structure of the former Convent of San Francisco de Asis is one of the most recognizable in the city. Today the building houses the Museum of Counterrevolutionary Bands. A U-2 spy plane stands on display outside. Inside, you find exhibits filled with weapons, photos, and maps depicting the struggle of the various banditos from 1960 to 1965. For a remarkable view of the city, you can climb the bell tower, taking in the pastel colors leading to the sea.

dayInfo.title: Cienfuegos – To Every Season
dayInfo.description: In the morning, you can find the aroma of freshly roasted coffee beans drifting down the streets of Cienfuegos. The scent disappears underneath the lingering fragrance of the sea. Tangible aromas and visceral colors overtake the day with your visit to the Cienfuegos’ Botanical Garden. The garden was established in the early 1900s and remains Cuba’s oldest botanical garden. The grounds encompass nearly 240 acres. Royal palms line the entry road to the garden creating an air of sophistication. Your guide for the day is an expert botanist keen on introducing you to the beauty and importance of the area. The grounds house over 2,000 plants, including 280 breeds of palm trees and 400 orchid breeds. The former sugar mill now lies in ruin adding to the ambiance of the garden. Hummingbirds flutter their wings in front of a freshly blossomed flower. The scent of the garden blends the semi-sweet with herbaceous qualities of the surrounding landscape. Emerald leaves and naturally pastel flower petals turn the garden into a living painting.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Coups and Captured Wars
dayInfo.description: The sunlight glints off the indigo waters at Playa Giron. The beauty of the coastline masks the history of the region. Today, you depart Cienfuegos and make your way back to Havana. En route you stop at Playa Giron, better known to the United States as The Bay of Pigs. The water hides some of the most diverse and pristine coral reefs edging the limestone coastline. A former sugar mill in the Town of Australia houses Fidel Castro’s former administration building used during the 1961 invasion. A British Sea Fury fighter aircraft and a replica tank of the original that destroyed the USS Houston stand outside the entrance to the museum. Inside the museum, you find weapons, flags, and garments used during the conflict between Cuban revolutionary forces and CIA-backed Cuban exiles. Walking through the gallery paints a different perspective than the one you are used to but the impact is significant. On the outskirt of Havana, you stop in the Principality of San Francisco de Paula to see Ernest Hemingway’s former home. The house was erected in the 19th century by a Catalan architect on a hill overlooking eastern Havana. Hemingway lived in the home from 1939 until 1960 when he left for America. While living in Cuba, Hemingway wrote two of his most notable works, The Old Man and the Sea, and For Whom the Bell Tolls . The windows and doors are open to give you a full view of the interior. A stand-up writing desk holds the author’s prized typewriter. The home has been preserved in such a way that it looks like the author recently stepped out and could return at any moment. Approximately 9,000 volumes of books fill the home, situated in every room, including the bathroom. In the living room, your guide points to an unassuming bowl, which was in fact designed by Pablo Picasso. The director of the museum meets with you to discuss the strong connection between Hemingway, his writings, and the Cuban people.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Inside the Art
dayInfo.description: Havana has a tangible draw and feels familiar. It is a city in which you could spend your entire life and feel comfortable in its endless surprises. After breakfast, you make your way to the bright neighborhood of Jaimanitas to step into the artwork. The artist Jose Fuster has been described as a cross between famous Spanish personalities Pablo Picasso and Antonin Gaudi. He has turned the neighborhood into a masterpiece encasing walls in ceramic tiles and building turrets overlooking the narrow streets. Statues rise out of private gardens. Whimsical murals drape over the walls. You feel as though you have stepped into a wonderland. Turn a corner and the walls fade into a piece of artwork beneath spiraling walkways and rippling fountains. Images of boats and waves splash against the buildings. You can find hidden Cuban flags and a mural of Granma yacht amongst the bursting paintings. The experience becomes surreal and enchanting, palpable and overwhelming all at once. Your guide leads you to the painter’s studio for insight into how he views the world, and more intimately, how he views Havana. Enjoy a farewell dinner at La Floridita, one of Hemingway’s favorite restaurants. The music roars through the dining room. You can sit and delight in a daiquiri, the way Hemingway would have.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Taking the Memories
dayInfo.description: Artists set up their canvas and easel along Paseo del Prado, often remarked as one of the most pristine streets in Havana. The 18th and 19th-century mansions outline the boulevard. Dual bronze lions frame the entrance to the walkway in the center of the street. Couples sit on marble benches and relax in the shade. Artists set to work capturing the waking city. Classic cars park alongside the edges of Parque Central. Groups of men linger around makeshift tables playing dominoes. The city returns to its bustling lifestyle. Whenever you are ready, your private transfer meets you at the hotel and escorts you to Jose Marti International Airport for your flight home.

placesVisited: Havana, Playa Larga, Cienfuegos, Trinidad
generalInfo: The colonial architecture will impress you, the music will stir you, and the people will inspire you on your custom tailored highlights of Cuba tour. The clapping sound of horse hoofs against cobblestone streets imitate the pulsing rhythms of the salsa bands performing in the restaurants across Havana. Pastel colored homes accentuate the variety of blue hues layering the Caribbean Sea. Powerful stone fortresses continue to guard the shoreline amidst the sweet aroma of sugar cane juice pressed before your eyes. Experience the lifestyle. Indulge in the culture. Enjoy the splendor of Cuba.

dayInfo.title: Havana – The Heart of Havana
dayInfo.description: The plane descends into Jose Marti International Airport in Havana. Tall lush grass carpets the countryside leading to the runway. Palm trees sway in the tropical breeze blowing across the landscape. Your private transfer awaits your arrival at the baggage claim eager to introduce you to the world famous city of Havana. Outside of the airport, you discover the aroma of fresh coconut. Classic cars cruise down the avenue leading to Old Town Havana. Local men stand on the thick wall of the Malecón, the seaside boulevard. They hold fishing rods, casting their lines into the pristine water below. Occasionally the Caribbean Sea breaks against the rugged coastline edging the sea wall and splashes onto the walkway. The city has an embracing quality, intriguing in its mixture of refurbished Spanish colonial architecture and crumbling historic facades. Locals offer friendly smiles as you pass by. At the corner of Plaza Vieja stands the nearly 115-foot tall tower of the Camera Obscura. The dark room uses the standard characters created by Leonardo d Vinci in the 15th century when he introduced the idea. The convex lens provides a spectacular view of the Old Town, from the rooftops of the old buildings to the structures across the bay rising up the hillside near the 16th-century Castillo de los Tres Reyes del Morro.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Enduring Eclecticism of Havana
dayInfo.description: In the morning, artists display their creations along the tree-lined walkway of the Paseo del Prado. Classic American cars pass beneath the glittering frames of bronze lions, marbled benches, and the continued elite ambiance created by the bygone glory of the Havana’s wealthiest families. Mansions and hotels from the 19th and early 20th centuries border the boulevard. The Moorish style of Hotel Sevilla accentuates the Spanish colonial connection to Cuba. Music fills the streets of Old Town, emanating from the endlessly vibrant street known as Calle Obispo. Your guide leads you through the rich architectural heritage of the Old Town, beginning with the Cuban Baroque style of Catedral de San Cristobal. Two unequal towers frame the façade designed by Italian architect Francesco Borromini in the 18th century. It is one of the oldest cathedrals in the Americas and once housed the remains of Christopher Columbus until the late 19th century. The rugged texture stems from the blocks of coral used during the construction, taking from the ocean floor along the Gulf of Mexico. Continue your exploration of the city with an immersive tour into the Afro-Cuban culture. Your guide leads you down Callejón de Hamel. Every Sunday at noon, the pulsing rhythm of rumba music erupts through the street. Murals depicting traditions and icons of African culture piece together images of the people. The walls depict feeling, and the music expresses emotion; even the overhanging roofs resemble sculptures turning the area into a temple for the Afro-Cuban experience, filled with powerful chants, interlocking drum patters, and undeniable spirit.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Captivating Images of a Unique Past
dayInfo.description: The sunlight washes over the Castillo de los Tres Reyes del Morro, bathing the stone in golden hues. The light tower rises above the calm cobalt water of the Caribbean Sea. After breakfast, you venture to Colon Cemetery, which contains more than 500 major mausoleums spanning nearly 140 acres. At the center of the grounds stands an octagonal neo-Byzantine church known as Capilla Central. A large fresco of the Last Judgment decorates the interior. Elegant trees dangle branches and leaves over the main bisecting lanes. Nobles in the 19th century competed to build elaborate tombs, eager to highlight their family’s social standing based on location and plot size. Marble reliefs on the triple-arched entrance gate dictate the elegant and historic ambiance of the cemetery. Your private guide leads you through the famous avenues to the most visited tombs, including the flower-bedecked grave of Amelia Goyri de Hoz. Visitors knock three times on the tombstone with one of the brass rings. They touch the tomb and request one favor, walking backward away from the tomb. Legend claims pilgrims should never turn their back on the La Milagrosa , The Miraculous One. The scents of budding flowers and palm trees harmoniously blend.
