The marble mausoleums glint in the sunlight. The rambunctious sounds of the city fade in the peaceful ambiance of the grounds.

dayInfo.title: Havana – The Havana Experience
dayInfo.description: The fertile land around Havana provides excellent crops for the farmers to produce the luscious produce. The various streets make each block feel more like a different neighborhood populating the larger area of Old Havana. Stroll through the local marketplace with your guide for an in-depth view of life in the city. The people’s market fills with fresh fruits and vegetables grown on the famous farms outside of the city. Vendors cut open pineapples showcasing the juicy yellow interior. Mounds of guavas and cauliflowers overtake the counters. Homemade sauces provide layers of flavor to every meal; their labels promote the vendor who makes each sauce from scratch in their home. You continue through the market to view the ration boards. Employees stand behind the counters and pass out the food, such as rice and beans, provided by the government. The Cuatro Caminos market is the city’s largest with beans, fruits, vegetables, and even animals for sale along the vast square block. The artistry of the food inspires a similar emotion as the quality of work on display in the art museums. The restored 1920s Palacio del Centro Asturiano houses more than 600 works of Ancient Egypt, Rome, and European Masters. The Palacio de Bellas Artes showcases Cuban art spanning 400 years, from the 17th century to present day. The Siesta, a 19th-century painting by Guillermo Collazo, shows a woman reposing in her villa while overlooking the Caribbean Sea. The realistic portrayal captures the beauty of Cuba in a simple glance.

dayInfo.title: Havana to Cienfuegos – Colors of Cuba
dayInfo.description: The music of Havana returns with the daylight. Bright pink Chevys cruise alongside the edge of Calle Obispo, near Ernest Hemingway’s old hangout at his favorite restaurant. Horses pull buggies across the cobblestone streets. Their hooves clop against the historic stones. Your private transfer meets you at your hotel and takes you to the town of Playa Larga, overlooking the sandy shores of the Caribbean Sea. The radiant turquoise water splashes against the pristine white sand. In the distance, the color changes to an alluring blue and teal. The sweet aroma of fresh coconut overtakes the semi-salty scent of the Caribbean Sea. A group of students awaits your arrival at the Kormacao Community Project. The space was founded in the early 21st century and provides training to young artists free of charge, emphasizing dance, theater, poetry, and music. The project helps inspire students by connecting them to their cultural heritage. You are welcomed with open arms and eager smiles. The music begins. The drums thump against the walls. The guitar strings hum over the pulsing beat. A small of group of students dance, blending traditional steps with modern movement. Their enthusiasm is captivating. The horns blow loud and smooth. Each sound builds on the other, resonating with emotion, telling more of the story than the title or the lyrics of the songs performed.

dayInfo.title: Cienfuegos – A Day from Bay to Beach
dayInfo.description: The 19th-century city of Cienfuegos rests on the edges of the natural bay. The Paseo del Prado del Paseo leads to the Malecón, wrapping around the vibrant waters providing an exquisite panorama. In the evening, poets serenade snuggling couples with the sound of the splashing water in the background. The distinct 20th-century palaces along Punta Gorda create a vibrant skyline of towers and domes. The relaxed seaside ambiance and handsome architecture set alongside the bastion of Cuba’s shrimp fishing fleets generate an unforgettable, gorgeous image. You leave behind the bayside streets of Cienfuegos for the beachside avenues of Trinidad. Horses saunter down the cobblestone streets. Locals sell bread from their bicycles, attaching the breadbaskets to the back of their seats. Sloped roofs and the towering church spire top the pastel painted homes. Follow your guide through the Museum of Architecture at the southeastern side of Plaza Mayor. The museum features exhibits of the upper-class domestic architecture of the 18th and 19th centuries. The structure itself was once the residence of the Iznaga family who owned an estate in the nearby Valley de los Ingenios. The city has a deep connection to its history, highlighted by the performances of the Ballet Folklorico de Trinidad.

dayInfo.title: Cienfuegos to Havana – Time By the Bay
dayInfo.description: The 18th-century fortress Castillo de Jagua watches over the coastline of Cuba. The intimidating structure continues to guard the port with a working drawbridge. Spend time in the morning visiting the local wonders of the city, from the beachside boulevard lined with elegant palm trees to the flavor local artists add to the city with the depiction of the spirit of Cuba. The Casa de la Cultura Benjamin Duarte was erected in the early 20th century with neoclassical details. Italian marble floors pave the interior. A wrought iron staircase leads to the rooftop cupola. The breeze carries the subtle aroma of freshly opened coconut. In the afternoon, your private transfer escorts you back to Havana. Along the way, you pass lush farmland where sugarcane grows into tall stalks. Tobacco leaves rustle in the breeze cast by passing cars. The familiar streets of Old Havana welcome you back. The music pouring out of the restaurants and bars creates a jovial atmosphere. The green leaves of yerba buena add graceful streaks of green to the fizzing clear cocktail of famous Cuban mojitos. You settle back into Havana with ease, noticing the local crowds enjoying their evening hanging out on the Malecón.

dayInfo.title: Havana – A Higher Standard
dayInfo.description: Vendors open up their book market in the oldest square in Havana. The surrounding trees shade the edges of the plaza and offer a comfortable location for locals to sit, read, and relax with respite from the tropical heat. A large machine stands outside a local shop with a man pressing sugarcane into the chopper. He turns the wheel. The gears grind the stalk into pure juice known as guarapo . He squeezes a touch of lime into the glass to offset the natural sweetness of the drink, creating another layer of refreshment. Your private transfer greets you at the hotel, ready to escort you to the airport for your flight home. Cuba offered a sincere welcome, immersing you into the culture and vibrant lifestyles of the locals along every step of your journey.

tourName: Immersive Cuba Tour: History, Culture, and People
placesVisited: Santa Clara, Caibarien, Remedios, Cayo Santa Maria, Havana
generalInfo: Step back in time when experiencing the layers of Cuba’s unique and captivating history. Travel along a singular road surrounded by the sea on either side. Journey on a vintage steam train through the lush landscape at the heart of the country. Follow the scent of dried leaves during a private tour of a cigar factory. Classic cars cruise cobblestone avenues. Horses clop down the boulevard pulling antique buggies. The sounds of rumba and salsa emphasize the vivacious murals, embellishing the culture and the country’s past. Your customized Cuba tour brings history to life, with you at its center.

dayInfo.title: Santa Maria – Back in Time
dayInfo.description: The lush greenery of the countryside surrounds the Santa Maria Airport. The long stretch of runway separates the manicured landscape from the towering tropical trees stretching to the hills in the distance. Your private transfer awaits your arrival at baggage claim, keen on introducing you to the culture of Cuba. Venture through the historic bastion of the city famous for its location as the final battle of the Cuban Revolution. When the guerillas, led by Che Guevara, overtook the city, the Batista regime fell. On the northern coast of the main island stands the spectacular key of Cayo Santa Maria, with a length of 10 miles and a width barely over one mile. At Pedraplen, the last leg of the scenic drive, you find the glistening water bordering both sides of the road. The fine powder white sand beaches frame the layered colors of the Caribbean Sea. Turquoise waves brush against the edges of the shore. In the distance, the bright color turns to cobalt along the horizon. The graceful beaches overtake a total of eight miles separated into nine sections along the indulgent soft sand. The sound of the waves crashing against the shoreline creates a paradisiacal atmosphere. The breeze rustles the palm fronds. Sand dunes grow as tall as six and half feet, acting as natural protection from the sea during tropical storms. Cayo Santa Maria offers a perfect introduction to the natural beauty of Cuba, and its prized coastline has brought visitors from around the world for centuries.

dayInfo.title: Santa Maria – Images of Sugar
dayInfo.description: The sunlight stretches over the layers of blue water and sparkles across the surface of the Caribbean Sea. The bleached white sand glints beneath the waving palm trees. The scent of strong, fresh coffee blends into the slightly salty aroma of the coastline. After breakfast, you venture to the fishing town of Caibarien, known as the White Village. Crumbling colonial buildings recall the town’s once glorious past. The sun-bleached facades conjure images of sugar, accentuated by the sugar mills dotting the streets. Water splashes over the sea wall on the Malecón. Weathered fishing boats return to the port from their daily endeavor at sea. Oceanside restaurants serve fresh crab, filling the air with a garlic, pepper, and buttery aroma. Take in a performance of the Caibarien Municipal Concert Band as they play classic Cuban music. The drumbeat drives the musicians. The pulsing rhythm leads the show, followed by the shouting horns, and humming guitar. Band members stroll into the crowd and help onlookers find their dance moves, letting the music guide them. Once your artistic hunger had been fulfilled, you venture to the train station to board the timeless transport used across Cuba. The windows of the rail car open to the emerald countryside, letting the breeze cool the tropical heat. Locals wave to the train as it passes through the town en route to Remedios.

dayInfo.title: Santa Maria – The National Park Difference
dayInfo.description: The peaceful atmosphere of the beach provides the relaxation for the sense in the morning. Waves crash against the sand. The scent of coconut fills the air. The window to your room frames the picture-perfect image of white sand and turquoise water. After breakfast, you return to mainland Cuba, bound for Guanayara National Park. Dense jungle covers the mountains. At the entrance of the park, you climb onto an old Russian military truck, refurbished to transport visitors around the lush vegetation and rugged terrain. The wind blows through your hair as your open-air transfer winds down the roads into the valley. Occasionally, the trees part for a pristine view of the Sierra del Escambray and Topes de Collantes ranges. Your guide stops the truck throughout the park to point out the native plant life, including flora believed to hold special healing properties. Bunches of bananas dangle from the canopy. Coffee beans bud beneath bushels of leaves. Cuba’s national bird, the Tocororo, lingers in the trees. Its feathers flash the red, blue, and white of the Cuban flag. It can grow to eleven inches in length with a fluffy tail. You hear the cascading sound of El Rocio waterfall before you see it. The water beads down the mountainside clinging to the rocks. Bamboo trees grow on the periphery. The water continues to stream into a natural pool hidden by the trees. The water shines shades of teal and mint in the sunlight.

dayInfo.title: Santa Maria – Capturing the Revolution
dayInfo.description: Return to the city of Santa Clara for the day to immerse yourself in the culture of the Revolution. The city maintains its sense of strength and feistiness in the student population attending the most prestigious university in Cuba outside of Havana. A 23-foot tall statue of Che Guevara overlooks the main square of Plaza Mayor. A series of comic book style murals decorate the walls on Carretera Central. The art satirically depicts Cuban-American relations with images such as Cuban helicopters taking away the Statue of Liberty. Fans of Che Guevara make their way to the mausoleum and monument honoring the revolutionary. The complex stands outside the town center, beckoning visitors with the enormous statue of Che marking its location. The 38 stone-carved niches commemorate the guerrillas who fought in the failed revolutionary attempt in Bolivia. The culture of the city combines a Cuban sense of rebellion with a magnetic friendliness. Meet a small local band that continues the tradition of adding sound to a silent movie. Their instruments help turn the city into a cinematic landscape, creating emotions set against the backdrop of history. When the reality of the city returns, you make your way to the Fabrica de Tabacos Constantino Perez Carrodeguas to tour the factory producing a range of the famous Cuban cigars.

dayInfo.title: Santa Maria to Havana – Journey to Havana
dayInfo.description: You take in the morning view one last time at Cayo Santa Maria. At times, it is hard to believe the vibrant colors of the ocean and the pure-white sand are real. After breakfast, your private transfer escorts you to a family operated print shop specializing in historic printing since the 19th century. The interior of the shop contains an aroma of leather and freshly bound books. Your guide takes out individual letter plates and demonstrates how to place and position the linotype machine. After the demonstration, you have the chance to print something yourself, using the techniques learned during your tour. The gears turn, making rambunctious sounds echoing in the small space. When you touch the paper, you can feel the fine threads in the thick texture. After your hands-on experience with the Cuban publishing industry, you continue on a scenic drive through the heart of the country en route to Havana. You arrive in the city to find people strolling along the cobblestone streets of Old Town. Classic Chevys and Fords cruise down the avenues besides refurbished buildings near Plaza Vieja. Baroque facades nestle against art nouveau structures. Horses pull carts along Parque Central. Their clopping hooves add to the vibrant sounds of the city. Stained glass windows decorate the west side of the square overlooking the fenced-in fountain at the center. The vivacious life of Havana feels like a different world than the beachside serenity of Cayo Santa Maria.

dayInfo.title: Havana – The Charms of Vintage Havana
dayInfo.description: On the fringes of the old city, historic buildings show the marks of time. Stone and brick fade. Cracks run across the façade of baroque window frames edged by distressed wooden balconies. The real life of Cuba’s capital leads to the remarkable colors of the refurbished Old Havana, where new life has been breathed into the architecture. Music spills out of the restaurants and bars on Calle Obispo. The narrow road connects Parque Central to the Plaza de Armas. The aroma of yerba buena , a herb comparable to mint and enhancing the flavor of freshly mixed mojitos, accentuates the vitality of the neighborhood. Antique weapons fill the galleries of San Carlos and San Severino de La Cabana fortresses, forming a unique collection of antique weapons, including a medieval catapult. The small fortress of Castillo San Salvadore de la Punta stands at the western edge of the harbor. The 16th-century four-sided structure takes visitors deeper into the history of the city. Walking around the city allows you to immerse yourself in the polished vintage grandeur of Cuba, showcasing the cherished past wrapped inside the present. Your guide leads you to a community project run by local women intent on teaching children traditional sewing techniques, with the intent of passing along Cuban culture, and a valued trade, to the next generation.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Uniquely Havana
dayInfo.description: The sea breeze rushes through the streets of Old Havana. The air sweeps across the trickling fountain of Plaza de San Francisco, providing a refreshing mist in the city’s tropical warmth. The tower of Basilica Menor de San Francisco de Asis looks out to the harbor. The water splashes over the Malecón walls, spraying local men casting their fishing lines into the sea. Distinctive Cuban art makes Havana glow with rich colors and vivacious images. Murals and textiles drape the walls of the two-block long alley Callejón de Hamel, known as the center of the Afro-Cuban culture in the city. Cultural dancers provide demonstrations of the music and the movements that separate the specific culture from that of Spanish decent. Sculptures depict treasured deities. Paintings display historical rituals. The sounds of rumba move down the street. The small fishing village of Cojímar pays homage to Ernest Hemingway as the location for the novel The Old Man and the Sea. The artistry of Old Town offers a perspective of Cuban daily life, taking you away from the dancing streets near the center of town, to a local mechanic specializing in the maintenance of the classic cars. Look under the hood of a vintage Cadillac. The frame says antique, but the engine comes from a Ford ambulance, providing the car with the power it needs to drive along the Cuban streets.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Away in Time
dayInfo.description: The rich history of the Taquechel Pharmacy Museum emanates from the ceramic jars displayed behind the counter. The jars hold herbal remedies that have cured and soothed the citizens of Havana for centuries. The colorful swirling texture of daiquiris fill the glasses lining the bar at El Floridita, Hemingway’s favorite restaurant. Famous visitors, such as Anna Pavlova and Winston Churchill frequented the neo-classical 19th-century hotel in the heart of Old Town. The morning sun casts a golden light over the historic cobblestone streets and refurbished architecture of the old city. Fountains trickle with water. The Caribbean Sea crashes against the walls of the Malecón, which has become a familiar, soothing sound connecting Havana with your time in Cayo Santa Maria. The markets fill with locals in search of fresh produce, from sweet peppers to indulgent pineapple. Spend time wandering through the lanes and alleys of Old Town once more before your private transfer escorts you to the Jose Marti International Airport for your flight home.

tourName: Move to the Music of Cuba: Salsa, Rumba, and Afro-Cuban Rhythms
placesVisited: Havana, Cienfuegos, Trinidad, Cojímar
generalInfo: Embrace the music on this eight-day Cuba tour for an enchanting vacation that introduces you to the rhythms of rumba, the seductions of salsa, and the appealing flow of Afro-Cuban songs. Join local musicians on tours of trendy clubs and dance halls, visit historic landmarks and cultural hotspots in Cuba’s charming cities, and savor a selection of gourmet Cuban cuisine as you move from one vibrant neighborhood to the next.

dayInfo.title: Havana - Welcome to Cuba’s Captivating Capital
dayInfo.description: The city of Havana exudes culture and its vibrant Spanish colonial districts reflect Cuba’s diverse historical influences. Colorful buildings create a rainbow cityscape, century-old cars cruise up and down bustling boulevards, and local musicians strum guitars beneath patios for travelers to stop and listen. You will welcome Havana’s warm energy as you land at the airport, clear customs, and transfer to accommodation within easy reach of the town center. Dinner this evening will give you a sense of what Cuban cuisine is all about as you tuck into the world-class regional creations of an award-winning chef.

dayInfo.title: Havana - Old Town Culture and an Evening of Salsa
dayInfo.description: Havana Old Town is a UNESCO Heritage Site that conjures images of the city’s cardinal colonial roots. Your guide will escort you through streets alive with color and culture that emanate from the vibrant atmosphere and Baroque buildings. The Cathedral of Havana is the oldest in the western hemisphere, a treasure trove of spiritual discoveries en route to the dazzling district circling Obispo Street. You will find gourmet hotspots for lunch and then visit the thumping art gallery and live music venue, Fábrica de Arte Cubano, to see exceptional installations and test the salsa skills you learned earlier in the day.

dayInfo.title: Trinidad - Inspired by Cienfuegos and Afro-Cuban Rhythms
dayInfo.description: The modern city of Cienfuegos is as progressive as it is historic, poignantly balancing the luxury amenities of the world’s fanciest destinations with the deep culture that resonates from the immaculate colonial-era architecture. You will stop here for lunch and a quick gallivant around the city to see the sights that grab the attention of travelers who flock to Cienfuegos from all over. Your guide will take you to Trinidad town next, where you will develop your salsa skills further and let the rumba rhythms seduce you at dance halls and Afro-Cuban clubs that peppe the town’s cobblestone streets.

dayInfo.title: Trinidad - Make Close Connections with Cuban Musicians
dayInfo.description: You will unravel the close connection between Cubaâs residents and the resonant history that reverberates through Trinidad. Your day begins in Plaza Mayor, a stoneâs throw from the Church of the Holy Trinity, Palacio Cantero, and Convento de San Francisco de AsÃ­s. You will also visit Afro-Cuban landmark Casa Templo de SanterÃ­a YemallÃ , before you join your salsa instructor for an advanced lesson. Tonight you will accompany Cuban musicians who share insight into the countryâs musical history, soundtrack your evening of song and dance, and show you a one-of-a-kind club within a cave where travelers and Latin celebrities mingle.

dayInfo.title: Havana - Fabulous Finds in Fusterlandia
dayInfo.description: You will return to Havana this morning, relishing an opportunity to visit one of Cuba’s most whimsical places en route to your gorgeous Havana hotel. Fusterlandia is Cuba’s art playground that was envisioned and constructed by the genius, José Fuster. Remarkably bright mosaics veil the installations of this fairytale gallery that captures the imagination of adults and children alike. The surreal sculptural pieces are also sublime backdrops for your series of travel photography. In the evening you will join a local musician at a jazz club for dinner, cocktails, and a night of impressive performances.

dayInfo.title: Havana - All Things Cuban Cuisine
dayInfo.description: The small fishing village of Cojímar is a resort town around the corner from Havana where you will lose yourself in the spectacular scenery that inspired the works of Ernest Hemingway. Beyond breathtaking images from every angle, Cojímar is a center for Cuban seafood and culinary hotspots riddle the coast, serving sensational dishes from sunup to sundown. You will taste-tour Cuban delicacies at a collection of charming restaurants, learning from the celebrity chefs and pairing your sumptuous snacks with prestigious bottles of wine or Cuban cocktails. You can also learn to cook Cuban cuisine, before you return to Havana.

dayInfo.title: Havana - The Pleasures of Leisure Time in Cuba
dayInfo.description: Havana hums from the night before as party-goers, explorers, and other travelers return to the bustling streets to grab a bite of delectable eats. You can join the activity in Havana’s vibrant neighborhoods, leisurely browsing the various boutiques and museums dotting the cityscape. You could head for the yacht club and catch a lavish liner out to sea, swim in the gentle waves, or spend the day poolside, lapping up the luxuries of your accommodation's amenities. Tonight you can dance the night away or enjoy a quiet dinner away from the crowds at Cuba’s premier restaurants.

dayInfo.title: Havana - Early Mornings in Cuba’s Charming Capital
dayInfo.description: You may wake up early to watch the sunrise over Havana with a fragrant cup of Café Cubano , or Cuban espresso. Downstairs, chefs will prepare beautiful breakfast bowls and delicious sweet treats for you to tuck into in the morning as you hope to see the city one last time before you leave. You can stroll down the street to see performers entertain early risers exploring outwards from the town’s main square. Your walk will lead you past colorful boutiques where you can pick up commemorative items, Cuban memorabilia, and other keepsakes to share with friends and family when you return.

tourName: Retracing the Steps of Cuban History: Havana & Cienfuegos Tour
placesVisited: Havana, Cienfuegos
generalInfo: The trepidations of the Cuban Missile Crisis and the Bay of Pigs are tangible memories. The easing of regulations has opened up new doors between the United States and Cuba. Your tour is custom tailored to discover the people and culture of the island nation, at times contrasting the perception of the country only 90 miles off the coast of Florida. Artists paint murals capturing the spirit of Havana. Cienfuegos is filled with pearled French architecture. Colonial buildings in Trinidad harken back to a bygone era. Cuba’s streets tell many stories, each as captivating as the next.

dayInfo.title: Havana – The Likes of Which You Have Never Seen
dayInfo.description: Your heart thumps with excitement as the plane descends onto the runway at Jose Mart International Airport. The high-rises of the contemporary neighborhood of Vedado stand tall against the background of turquoise water from the Atlantic Ocean. The dome of the Capital Building is reminiscent of the United States Capital in Washington D.C., which it was modeled after. The plane lands, and you are about to step into Cuba, a prospect you never could have imagined. Cubans crowd around the exit near baggage claim holding signs for family and friends returning from abroad. Your private transfer greets you at the airport and escorts you to Revolution Square. The stone tower rises over 350 feet above the plaza. At its base stands a large marble figure representing Jose Marti, the father of Cuban independence. Images of Che Guevara and Camilo Cienfuegos decorate the buildings opposite the tower. Continue to Hotel Nacional de Cuba; a luxury establishment erected in the 1930s. Famous visitors have included Frank Sinatra and Marilyn Monroe. The edifice stands atop a strategic hillside overlooking the Malecón, the famous seaside boulevard wrapping around the edge of Havana. Beneath the hotel is a bunker where Fidel Castro and Che Guevara resided during the Cuban Missile Crisis. A walkway leads to the stone construction burrowed into the hill. Posters explaining the tension between Cuba and America line the walls. You find a map pinpointing the location of Cuban forces and missiles during the crisis.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Bringing the Past to Life
dayInfo.description: The aroma of freshly brewed Cuban coffee enlivens Havana before the music begins. On the outskirts of Havana Central, the Atlantic Ocean splashes against the sea walls. After breakfast, you meet with an architect involved in the restoration of Old Havana, returning the crumbling facades along the side streets to colonial grandeur. The architect also acts as your guide along the cobblestone avenues of the historic city. Each square has a unique feature creating a distinctive ambiance unlike any other plaza in Havana. The music of the day spills out of restaurants and cafes. Musicians linger in the small avenues and mold the classic soundtrack of Old Havana. The Plaza de Armas once acted as the social center of the city, beginning with its inception in the 16th century. The name stems from the military events and ceremonies that took place in the square. Castillo de la Real Fuerza encloses the plaza. The fortification began in the mid 16th century to protect Havana from pirates and foreign navies. French corsair Jacques de Sores had destroyed the previous castle and subsequently plundered the city. In the afternoon, you make your way to Havana’s first English bookstore, Cuba Libro, to engage in a discussion about the arts, culture, and the importance of reading with engaged citizens.

dayInfo.title: Havana – History of a Complex Relationship
dayInfo.description: The morning sun peels back the shade across Havana. Couples stroll hand in hand along the Malecón listening to the water crash against the sea wall. After breakfast, you meet with a university professor who specializes in U.S.-Cuban relations. The discussion allows you time to match your understanding of the topic with that of the Cuban perspective. Make your way to the Museum of Fine Arts to stroll along the three separate structures forming the museum collective. The main focus of your visit is at the Palace of Fine Arts, which houses artwork created by Cubans, focusing mainly on pieces between the 17th and 19th centuries. The elegant exterior sets the tone of the interior, where you find graceful paintings depicting life in Cuba, along with religious subjects and landscape scenes. Continue to the Fortaleza de San Carlos de la Cabana, set at the mouth of Havana Harbor. The Spanish erected the edifice in the 18th century along the east ridge of the harbor. The fortress spans 2,296 feet from end to end, covering nearly 25 acres. The refreshing sea breeze blows across the stone courtyard. The Museo de Fortificaciones y Armas expresses the bloody history of the fort and the bay. The setting provides you with a fabulous panorama of Havana spread before you.

dayInfo.title: Havana – Days to Remember
dayInfo.description: Cuba has a scintillating connection to art of all types, whether it's music, dancing, painting, or writing. On the outskirts of Havana, in a suburb known as San Francisco de Paula, stands Ernest Hemingway’s former home. The famous American author lived in Cuba from 1939 to 1961. The home has been renovated so well that it looks as though Hemingway left five minutes before you arrived and could return at any minute. The author wrote two of his award-winning novels while living in Cuba: For Whom the Bell Tolls and The Old Man and the Sea. The latter novel took place in the fishing village of Cojimar, located nearly 11 miles away. Animal trophies decorate the walls. Fishing rods are hung with care. Galley and correspondence fill the rooms, along with more than 9,000 books from Hemingway’s personal library. A small standing desk continues to hold his typewriter. As of 2016, the Finca Foundation received permission from the United States and Cuban governments to construct an archive with wet and dry conservation laboratories. In the neighborhood of Vedado, you enter the famous Colon Cemetery and follow your guide through the historic grounds to view the graceful mausoleums of wealthy families, revolutionary heroes, and mythological figures.

dayInfo.title: Cienfuegos – Timing of the Story
dayInfo.description: While in Havana, you have witnessed great stories and created some of your own. Fishermen set out along the sea wall of the Malecón and cast their lines in search of a catch worth celebrating. Locals in Old Havana head to their rooftop in search of quiet space to enjoy the city. Children let their kites loose into the sea breeze. Classic American cars roam around the city, adding to Cuba’s unique story. After breakfast, your transfer greets you at the hotel and escorts you east to the Zapata Wetlands. Outside of Havana, the streets narrow. Cars share the road with tractors and horse-drawn carriages. A local expert in ecology and the consistent conservation efforts of Cuba meets you at the edges of the wetlands. A small recreation of a Taino village, the aboriginal people of Cuba, juts out into the heart of Treasure Lake. Thatched rooftops shade the huts from the tropical sun. Larger than life sculptures depict the daily lives of the villagers. Visit a large crocodile farm, where approximately 10,000 pre-historic reptiles showcase the success of Cuba’s conservation efforts. Your guide explains that in the 1950s and 1960s, the native crocodile in Cuba was near extinction. You can also see the Manjuari, or Cuban Gar, known as a living fossil. The fish is more than six feet in length with a greenish tint that almost resembles a crocodile. Continue to Playa Giron, which Americans know best as the Bay of Pigs. A small coastal village remains, along with a museum dedicated to telling the tale of the 1961 class between Cuban rebel forces and the CIA-supported Cuban exiles. A Sea Fury fighter aircraft stands aside the Cuban flag in front of the museum entrance.

dayInfo.title: Cienfuegos – Art and Colonialism
dayInfo.description: In the pearled city of Cienfuegos, the white buildings reflect the radiance of the sparkling bay. The French settled the city in the 19th century, and the beauty once celebrated continues to shape the city in various ways. After breakfast, your guide leads you to an art school where students and faculty adopt the colorful images of everyday life in Cienfuegos. Meet with the students to learn about what inspires them in an ever-evolving Cuba. Some mention the art nouveau and neoclassical buildings. Others are inspired by the impressive Jose Mart Park located near the Paseo del Prado that leads to the Malecón. Another student discusses the aroma of the sea and the lush emerald color of yerba mate when mixed in a mojito. Depart for the city of Trinidad, which retains its colonial charm from its inception in the 16th century. The Escambray Mountains outline the majestic architecture to the north. The turquoise Caribbean Sea frames the city to the south. Pastel painted homes run alongside cobblestone streets. Horses clop along the stone-paved roads in the car-less city center. Musicians seduce passersby at the Casa de la Musica. Café tables fill the stairway leading to the restaurant at the top of the moderate incline. The aroma of mojitos and cuba libres emanate from the bar. The Historic Municipal Museum is situated in the 19th-century Borrell family mansion located in the Plaza Mayor. The neoclassical style rooms exhibit the wealth of the family attributed to the sugarcane boom.

dayInfo.title: Cienfuegos – Upraising the Farmer
dayInfo.description: Independent business is still a relatively new venture and different source of revenue for most Cubans. After breakfast, your guide leads you to the farmers market in Cienfuegos to view the type of merchandise on offer. Mounds of produce, from zucchini to onions, pineapple to potatoes lines the stalls. Antique scales measure the weight of the goods people purchase. The brightly painted large room fills with locals. In the back, your guide points out a ration list, providing you with insight into the continued rationings of dietary staples such as beans and rice. You make your way to the spirited city of Santa Clara. Che Guevara led a small group of rebels to capture an armored train, turning the tide of the Cuban Revolutionary War. Santa Clara is also home to the most prestigious university outside of Havana, lending itself as an encouraging source of the rebellious temperament. Before you tour the city, you meet with a group of local seniors for an insider’s view of Cuban retirement. The men enjoy congregating outside cafes or in the Parque Vidal to play dominos. The women have taken to crocheting and various types of art in the hopes of selling their work in the crafts market. Continue to the Ernesto Che Guevara Monument, adorned with a 22-foot tall bronze statue of the rebel leader. The 38 stone-carved niches commemorate the guerillas killed in a failed revolutionary attempt in Bolivia. A large fresco behind the statue of Che depicts the rebel leader meeting with Fidel Castro.

dayInfo.title: Cienfuegos – Crafting the Story of Cuba
dayInfo.description: In the morning, the water from the bay laps gently at the sea wall along the Malecón. Palm trees cast shadows over the streets; their large fronds sway in the quiet breeze. The powerful Castillo de Jagua crowns the mouth of the bay. The Spanish built the fortress in the 18th century to protect the port against pirates. Every year in May, land crabs march along the terrain, moving from the base of the mountains to the sea. They lay their eggs in the Caribbean, crossing busy streets to do so. The sunlight washes over the former palace on the Punta Gorda at the end of the main avenue. The red-tiled cupola shines against the indigo hues of the water. The Moorish arcades give the palace a Mediterranean atmosphere. Today, you can enjoy Cienfuegos at your leisure. Soon your private transfer will meet you at your hotel and escort you to Jaime Gonzalez Airport for your flight home.
